text:
W. KAMAU BELL:
Whatever America is,

we know that it is
made up from people all

over the world who
come to this place
to contribute to this country.

But recently, in this
heightened political climate,

there's been a lot of
talk about the terms
"immigrant" and "refugee."

But what I want to know
is, what's the difference?
[music playing]
Let's figure this out.

An immigrant is "a person who
comes to a country to take
up permanent residence."

But a refugee is a
specific type of immigrant.

A refugee is a legal term
defined as "a person who

flees to a foreign
country or power

to escape danger
or persecution."

Basically, immigrants are making
a choice to leave their country

for a better job or a better
education or marriage,

whereas refugees are forced
to leave their country,

and therefore they have to
undergo an intense application

process in order to prove their
need and urgency to escape.

But why all the controversy
around immigrants and refugees?

Some people say immigrants are
coming here to take our jobs.

But multiple studies have
shown that immigrants
are entrepreneurs.

Immigrants start
businesses at a higher
rate than native-born citizen.
Immigrants are taking our jobs.
They're creating new jobs.
Thank you, immigrants.
But what about refugees?

Well, some people think
refugees are going to move
here and become terrorists.
But here are the facts.

Since 1980, after strict
procedures were put in place

to vet refugees who
move to this country,

the number of fatal
terrorist attacks

committed by refugees in
the United States of America
is zero--

none, zip, zero,
zilch, nada, goose egg.
I see your need for concern.

The thing we have
to understand is

that immigrants and
refugees have always
made this country stronger.

And they will continue to
make this country stronger
if we continue to let them in.
